sheets.Sheet1.Name: Lionel Messi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: There was a point last year when it felt like Cristiano Ronaldo had started to get the upper hand in his personal obsession to displace Lionel Messi as the sport’s principal showman. Ronaldo scored goals from any distance and any angle and you just have to watch the film-documentary about him to understand that it is the competition with Messi, more than anything else, that drives him to these heights. Yet his old adversary, once again, has that little extra on top. Messi is still the player you always want on the ball. He is still the player who takes the sport to its greatest heights and there is still that instantaneous ripple of expectation when he moves on to the ball, wherever he is on the pitch and whoever he is playing against. Remember, just to cite one example, that exquisitely delivered nutmeg to find the gap between James Milner’s legs when Manchester City played at Camp Nou in the Champions League? You might recall how, high in the stands, Pep Guardiola could be seen with his head in his hands, howling with laughter at the impudence of his former player. Messi does it as a matter of routine: the speed, the balance, the self-belief to back himself every time, the anticipation, the knowledge of how to make the ball do whatever he wants. And that hunger. Messi has been at the top of his sport for years but never leaves the sense that he wants to stop to admire the view. There is never a flicker of complacency, just that fixed expression and the clear sense that no matter who the opposition put on him, whoever kicks him and however much they try to negate him, he will always find a way. There is not enough said about the personal discipline that must go into maintaining that standard of excellence, but it is one of the principal reasons why this small man with the rarest gifts is a giant of the sport.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Cristiano Ronaldo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It has been a strange year for the Ballon d'Or incumbent, although here even mild decline is a relative thing. In a year when Cristiano Ronaldo seemed more or less the same, just slightly less so, he was the top pick on the Top 100 list of just 7% of judges  after careering off as runaway leader last year with a massive 74%. At the same time Real Madrid's all-time galáctico, by mid-December, had still managed to score 52 goals for club and country, set a new Guinness world record for all-time "most liked" person on Facebook, and churned out a familiarly relentless stream of goals, assists, shots and arm-waggling sprints from that bespoke centre forward role. Aged 30, with 12 years of elite level football behind him, there is a sense of Ronaldo's powers not so much diminishing as condensing. This, it seems, is his way of ageing. He still runs a lot, just with an ever narrower range, more focused on shooting and scoring. Even in a so-so non-trophy year by mid-December Ronaldo still managed 327 shots at goal for club and country. His detractors will point out that he has been the hammer of the second-rankers with 28 goals – more than half his annual total – in eight games against Malmo, Espanyol, Shakhtar Donetsk, Getafe, Granada and Armenia. His supporters might point to the fact he is still jaw-droppingly prolific even in an unsettled Real team, under a manager with whom he appears to have an anti-chemistry, testament not just to his talent but to that relentless champion's will.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Neymar
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Up to third and heading even higher in the future: Neymar is surely destined to be the world’s best player, and he is still just 23. He has won the treble with Barcelona, been joint top scorer in the Champions League, including a goal in the final, and has played a leading role so far this season in the absence of Lionel Messi with performances that have been consistently extraordinary and fantastically fun too. That was perhaps best encapsulated by the remark made by his team-mate Luis Suárez: “We all know our roles,” the Uruguayan said. “I don’t dribble round three or four players like Neymar does.” It’s true, Neymar does, over and over again, a trail of bamboozled defenders left in his wake. “He’s electric. When he runs into the area, either they commit a penalty or he scores,” Luis Enrique said. And if that might sound frivolous, it is not: the productivity in 2015 has been quite astonishing. Dunga described him as the best player in the world and when he scored an outrageously good goal against Villarreal, flicking the ball over the defender before volleying it in, Gerard Piqué admiringly insisted: “I have no idea how he did it. If I tried that, I would fall over.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Luis Suárez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For Luis Suárez, fourth place in the list reflects a stunningly sustained contribution to one of the great club football triple-acts. In 2015 he hit the jackpot, finding at the age of 28, after more than 500 games as a professional, the extreme outer limits of his own brilliant striking talent. Suárez was the No1 pick of 8% of judges, more than Cristiano Ronaldo, but his influence is stamped right across that top four. Switched to the centre at the end of last year the Uruguayan was Barcelona's catalyst, glue, and alternately the brains and muscle of the side's sublime attacking trident, creating space with his movement and hustle, linking brilliantly and helping to elevate both his front-running partners to new, or in Messi's case renewed, levels. More than 40 goals for club and country were his most tangible contribution. Missing the Copa América because of his ban for biting during the 2014 World Cup is the only negative, and the most obvious argument against nudging Suárez, the star player who makes other star players play, even higher.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Robert Lewandowski
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Pep Guardiola sounded strangely unenthusiastic when Bayern Munich signed Robert Lewandowski in the summer of 2014, like a small boy shrugging his shoulders after getting a Playstation at Christmas. “I congratulate the club to sign a player like Lewandowski,” Guardiola said, raising suspicions that Bayern’s manager really would have liked another midfielder instead. How ridiculous those misgivings feel now. After a slightly awkward start to 2015, which began with Lewandowski trotting off in the 71st minute of a 4-1 defeat to Wolfsburg in January, he has cemented his reputation as the deadliest striker in Europe and risen 25 places in our rankings. A significant moment in his Bayern career arrived when he scored twice in the 6-1 victory over Porto in the last eight of the Champions League in April and his numbers since then are startling. There was the five-goal burst in the space of nine minutes that turned a 1-0 deficit into a 5-1 lead against Wolfsburg in September, which sparked a run of 15 goals in six games for club and country, and he was inspirational in Poland’s successful qualifying campaign for Euro 2016. Lewandowski and Guardiola are a good fit after all.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thomas Müller
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “It’s not easy to find somebody who plays this strangely,” is how the self-styled “space interpreter” once described his positional vagueness. But this year Thomas Müller, the son of a BMW engineer, has mostly been employed in a more central role at Bayern Munich, behind Robert Lewandowski. Closer proximity to the goal has resulted in increased output. Müller is on course for his highest-scoring season, having been prolific in the Bundesliga already. A very successful penalty-taking technique – Müller waits for the 'keeper to make up his mind and does not look at the ball before his strike – has added to his impressive numbers.  “Müller can play badly for 90 minutes but still score,” his former youth coach at Bayern, Hermann Gerland, once said. Louis van Gaal, the Dutch coach who mentored his breakthrough at the Allianz Arena in 2009, is an admirer: Manchester United were keen to lure him to Old Trafford this summer, but Bayern have declared him officially “unsellable”. Müller, a proud Bavarian, is so highly valued for his effectiveness on the pitch and leadership qualities off it that there’s already talk of the 26-year-old taking on an important role at the club after his career.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Zlatan Ibrahimovic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Zlatan Ibrahimovic returns to the top 10 after a year that saw him win the league with Paris St-Germain and almost single-handedly take Sweden to Euro 2016. Still a talisman for club and country, he seems determined to make the most of his final years in top-level football. He scored 19 goals in 24 matches in the 2014-15 season as PSG won the league by eight points and had 12 goals in 12 league games in early December 2015 as his club opened up a chastening 15-point gap at the top of the table. And that was despite persistent injury problems at the start of the 2015-16 season.  Controversy, as always, was never far away and in March he lost his temper after a game against Bordeaux, swore at the referee and said that France was "a shit country". The National Front did not take take kindly to his comments and its president, Marine Le Pen, said he could leave if he did not like living there. He later apologised.  A personal highlight of the year came in November when he scored three of the four goals as Sweden eliminated Denmark in the Euro 2016 play-offs, the final one a beautiful free-kick from 22 yards out.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Manuel Neuer
sheets.Sheet1.Profile:
No goalkeeper goes further than Bayern Munich’s and Germany’s Manuel Neuer. The 29-year-old has long left his line behind to become a truly postmodern No1, a defender in gloves, a keeper who dictates the rhythm and direction of his team’s buildup play with pinpoint passes from his own box. 
When he was 13, coaches at his boyhood club Schalke were so concerned by his lack of height that they considered using him as an outfielder. Neuer believes he could have held his own there too, but a growth spurt put him back on track. 
This year has been a relatively barren one for the World Cup winner, delivering only another Bundesliga title with Bayern – his third in four seasons at the Allianz Arena – but Neuer continues to set the benchmark for all-round ability. 
His ease on the ball makes it much harder for opponents to press the defenders – he is always available as an outlet – and his frequent interventions outside the box stifle many threats before they materialise. “It’s riskier not to intercept the ball,” he says, “because world class strikers make very few mistakes.” Needless to say, neither does he.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Agüero
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Sergio Agüero is one of world football's surest things in front of goal and the highest-placed Premier League player on the list. The explosive Manchester City striker has had another prolific year despite having suffered two spells on the sidelines due to a knee injury and a troublesome hamstring. His three goals in five games helped Argentina reach the Copa América final in the summer but, undoubtedly, his highlight of 2015 was the jaw-dropping one-man wrecking-ball job against Newcastle, in which he showcased his ability to poach, play off the shoulder, strike from distance and generally terrorise defenders like only a select few can. His five goals in 20 second-half minutes made it clear why the forward is generally considered to be the Premier League's one true global star. His razor-sharp movement makes him a nightmare to mark but also a perfect foil for creators at club and country, such as David Silva, Lionel Messi and Kevin De Bruyne. His nerveless last-minute penalty against Borussia Mönchengladbach provided the springboard for City's qualification for the last 16 of the Champions League. Uncomplicated, unerring and universally respected, his questionable fitness is his only drawback. He is in the midst of his peak years, and English football is lucky to have him.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Alexis Sánchez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Arsenal's talisman is, according to Arsène Wenger, like a lion hunting his prey. “He is this kind of killer,” Wenger says. “When they go, it is to kill and after, they have to stop. His style is very explosive.” Of all the many compliments lavished upon Alexis Sánchez since his arrival in English football, this one gets to the heart of his no-holds-barred approach. The forward leaves nothing on the field; he goes and he goes; he is utterly relentless. It is supposed to take time for an overseas player to settle in England but Sánchez hit the ground running and he has carried on and on. Consistently superb during his debut season, when he helped Arsenal to win the FA Cup and scored a cracker in the final, he has continued to drive them and even fitted in a Copa América triumph with Chile over the summer. Sánchez has found the perfect match for his qualities in the Premier League and he is more than just a goalscorer. He injects the urgency and tempo, making things happen. His combination of pace, power, incision and ruthlessness is effective enough but when it is allied to his levels of industry and hunger, it is deadly.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Paul Pogba
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Manuel Pellegrini asserted before Manchester City’s first Champions League meeting with Juventus this season that Paul Pogba still had a way to go before he could be considered the equal of Yaya Touré. The evidence on the pitch later suggested otherwise. Pogba dominated both encounters, alternating muscular interventions with eye-catching technique. Great responsibility was heaped on his shoulders after Andrea Pirlo and Arturo Vidal left Juventus this summer, but after a disappointing start he has risen to the task. Pogba can today be considered the best box-to-box midfielder on the planet. He is also the highest-ranked Serie A player on this list.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Andrés Iniesta
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: This time last year there was a sense that Andrés Iniesta was on the wane but he has proved that view to have been premature, a steadfastly excellent 2015 leading to a 16-place jump from last year's ranking. He orchestrated much of the play behind Barcelona's vaunted front three during a treble-winning season that he capped with a man-of-the-match display in the Champions League final. And he continued in that vein after a rare summer break, his deftly destructive performance in November's magnificent 4-0 clásico victory earning applause even from Real Madrid supporters and, perhaps, convincing one of our 115 judges to rank him as the best player in the world this year.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Eden Hazard
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Premier League's player of last season, and the highest ranked Chelsea player in the poll, has dipped to date this season. Eden Hazard's busy trickery and slippery skill are still very much in evidence but the goals have rather dried up for his club – not so for Belgium – and that old habit of neglecting defensive duties actually cost him his place in the side on a few occasions in the autumn. Hazard is still the Londoners' most progressive attacking force, however, and is a player who is continually courted by Real Madrid and Paris Saint-Germain.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Kevin De Bruyne
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Where has the callow youngster who was discarded by Chelsea two years ago gone? Kevin De Bruyne has been the breakout star of 2015, starting it by destroying Bayern Munich in January, finishing it as the most expensive player in Manchester City’s history. The terrifying thing is that the Belgian, who is the highest new entry on this year's list, is surely only going to get better. De Bruyne’s performance for Wolfsburg in that 4-1 thrashing of Bayern must go down as one of the finest individual displays this year. He scored two stunning goals and effectively ended Dante’s Bayern career, leaving the Brazilian centre-back in a spin with his driving, twisting runs on the break. And not many players beat Manuel Neuer so emphatically. José Mourinho must be furious with himself for letting De Bruyne join Wolfsburg in January 2014. The 24-year-old was never given a chance to prove himself at Chelsea, but that transfer was the making of him. The forward was exceptional in Germany last season, scoring 16 goals and making 28 assists to help Dieter Hecking’s side finish second and win the German Cup. De Bruyne scored the decisive goal in the cup final against Borussia Dortmund. He made the second-most chances in the top five European leagues last season and that persuaded City to sign him for £54m in the summer. He has settled well after returning to the Premier League, scoring frequently for his new side, and he played a pivotal role in City reaching the last 16 of the Champions League, drilling in a stoppage-time winner in the 2-1 victory over Sevilla in October. Manuel Pellegrini, City’s manager, has admitted that spending that much money on De Bruyne was a gamble, but the player has been worth every penny so far.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Arturo Vidal
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: They called him "Re Arturo" – the king – in Italy, where the Chilean box-to-box maestro Arturo Vidal won four Serie A titles in as many years and helped Juventus to a runners-up medal in the Champions League. But the Bianconeri’s willingness to sell the 28-year-old to Bayern Munich in the summer reflected concerns about his long-term fitness. Since Vidal's move back to the Bundesliga (he started his European career at Bayer Leverkusen), the strong and direct midfielder has struggled a little to adapt to Pep Guardiola’s passing game but he remains a formidable force.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gareth Bale
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Gareth Bale puts the W into Wales. Chris Coleman has built a steely defence but it took Bale's brilliance to turn draws into victories, as he scored seven of his country's 11 goals during the Euro 2016 qualifying campaign to send the Welsh to a major tournament for the first time since 1958. There is more to Wales than Bale but rarely has one player driven a national team so far. At club level Bale's second season at Real Madrid was less successful than his first, particularly in the Champions League, and injuries and upheaval at the club did not help. But he has shown sporadically that he retains exceptional athleticism and skills and if he were to be put up for sale, as many clubs wish, Real could hope to recoup the world record fee that they paid for him.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Carlos Tevez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It speaks of Carlos Tevez’s importance for Juventus that the club signed not one, but three players to replace him. Paulo Dybala, Mario Mandzukic and Simone Zaza all have their qualities, but there are plenty of fans who would trade them back for "El Apache" in a heartbeat. Tevez’s 29 goals – including seven in the Champions League – fired Juventus to the brink of a treble last season, but his work rate and selfless contributions to buildup play have been even harder to replicate. Now back with his boyhood club, Boca Juniors, he ranks highest of any player competing outside Europe.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David de Gea
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Outwitting Real Madrid and convincing David de Gea to sign a new contract might be Manchester United’s greatest triumph so far in the post-Ferguson era. The goalkeeper's improbable feats between the sticks helped United return to the Champions League and has kept them towards the front of this season's Premier League title race. He has demonstrated his mental strength by putting the transfer saga behind him and immediately responding with top-class performances. He has made the extraordinary routine, although even by his standards the save from José Fonte’s header that helped United to an improbable victory at St Mary’s in September was phenomenal. Iker Casillas remains Spain's No1 in the eyes of the country's manager and few others.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: James Rodríguez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: James Rodríguez did not win any major trophies with Real Madrid in his first season at the Santiago Bernabéu but that may ultimately have underlined his importance rather than serving to diminish it. It was his absence through injury, after all, that was one of the most significant reasons for results deserting Carlo Ancelotti’s team. They had been impressive with him already, but that made them see just how important he was too. The team that had won 22 consecutive games and the World Club Cup ended the season empty-handed. He has provided touch, vision and a collection of lovely goals, despite not playing in his favoured No10 position.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ivan Rakitic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: In just over a year Ivan Rakitic won the Europa League as the captain of Sevilla – and was named man of the match in the final – then joined Barcelona, where he had to replace Xavi Hernández, arguably the greatest Spanish player of all time. Despite the pressure and the need to learn a whole new style he won the treble, scoring the opening goal in the Champions League final. He beat his former club, where they still love him, 5-4 in the European Super Cup. And he got married too. Who writes his scripts? “Someone good,” he says.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Philipp Lahm
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: By the World Cup and Bayern Munich treble-winner’s standards, 2015 was an unremarkable year. Philipp Lahm, though, was just as supernaturally solid as ever, at times excelling in yet another role for Pep Guardiola, on the right flank in midfield. The “football robot,” as Borussia Dortmund's Thomas Tuchel has called the 32-year-old, has not missed a single game injured since returning from a three-month lay-off with a broken ankle in March. The Bayern captain is targeting a historic fourth championship in a row and a second Champions League triumph after retiring from international duty, but Germany will miss him dearly at the Euros in France.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Arjen Robben
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Arjen Robben's speed and wriggly brilliance make him impossible to contain when he is at his best and that is why he was Bayern Munich's joint-top scorer in the Bundesliga last season despite missing the final two months of the campaign through injury. His goals – and his service for the team's other main marksman, Robert Lewandowski – had helped Bayern establish their domestic untouchability by then but his absence cost the Germans heavily in the Champions League semi-finals, where they lost to Barcelona. The club signed Douglas Costa in the summer in recognition that Robben, aged nearly 32, was on the way down but the Dutchman responded superbly, making a devastating start to the new season before being struck down again by injury. He recovered in time to increase Arsenal's pain in the 5-1 Champions League victory in November.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David Alaba
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: An extremely versatile player, David Alaba is going from strength to strength and is becoming one of Pep Guardiola’s favourite players – not bad for a 23-year-old. A full-back at Bayern Munich with the freedom to roam, he scored a wonderful goal against Arsenal in the Champions League in November, popping up in an advanced central area to power past Francis Coquelin and Santi Cazorla before beating Petr Cech with a beautifully curled shot. He plays in central midfield for Austria and was the driving force behind their impressive qualifying campaign as they reached France with two games to spare.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Busquets
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: If it were up to Luis Enrique, Sergio Busquets would be even higher up this list. “He is a unique player,” the Barcelona manager said in November. “He is the most complete and, for me, best midfielder in the world without a doubt.” He has a point: perhaps it is too easily forgotten that Barça’s metronome is still only 27 and keeps quietly improving while those in front make a louder noise. Busquets is a remarkably astute footballer, keeping order as his peers improvise and enjoying a little more licence to help out with attacks these days, too. He won his second treble of the Champions League, La Liga and the Copa del Rey in 2015; it is hardly the achievement of a mere water-carrier.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Javier Mascherano
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Javier Mascherano remains one of Barcelona’s most reliable performers. He has been a solid partner for Gerard Piqué in central defence, with his anticipation and reading of the game ensuring that his lack of height was rarely exposed, while his versatility has made him a useful option in midfield when Luis Enrique wants to close games down. Others took the plaudits, but he played a big part in Barcelona’s treble, while he also helped Argentina reach the final of the Copa América. There is not a side in the world that would not want Mascherano. He is a ferocious competitor.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mesut Özil
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Arsenal's purring, super-deluxe accessory can polarise opinion. The critics in England and his native Germany complain he drifts out of big games; that he decorates rather than designs. But, now established as Arsenal's undisputed No10 in a squad replete with them, he feels more involved and influential, and climbs 28 places in this year's list. Do not confuse his undemonstrative manner with a lack of passion or application. Racking up the assists so far this season, Mesut Özil is that rare player who can produce a flash of sumptuous class to remind everybody why they fell in love with the game in the first place.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The second highest new entry on this year's list. Jürgen Klopp left Borussia Dortmund last summer but the club did its utmost to ensure it did not endure another, perhaps even more painful separation, as it secured Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang to a new contract. The Gabon international had his doubters after his first season but he won everyone over in his second, hitting 26 goals in all competitions despite Dortmund's struggles. This season he looks even better, improving his finishing and interplay while retaining all his speed and explosiveness. Two hat-tricks in a week in October, against Gabala and Augsburg, helped confirm him as one of the most dangerous strikers in European football.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Antoine Griezmann
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Antoine Griezmann scored twice against Levante in early January to signal his improved finishing skills, which would eventually leave him with 22 goals for the 2014-15 season in La Liga – a tally bettered only by Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi. Three consecutive braces in April showcased his full repertoire, with the goals ranging from instinctive poaches to an acrobatic scissors kick winner against Deportivo. Beyond his goals, the Frenchman is a vital creator for club and country thanks to his pace, technique and inventiveness and, indeed, in Atlético's first match of this season he delivered victory with another of his assets, a perfectly taken free-kick.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Yaya Touré
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It is not unfair to say that Yaya Touré, who will be 33 in May, does not quite present the threat of old but equally accurate is the fact that Manchester City badly miss him when he is not around. Touré scored 13 times last season but has struggled to get going this term. It suggests a sharp tailing-off from his almost unplayable best, yet at the same time it is hard to imagine Manuel Pellegrini’s side winning the Premier League without another prominent contribution from the Ivorian. Touré’s crowning achievement this year – and, he might say, in his entire career – came in February, when he captained his national team to its first Africa Cup of Nations title since 1992.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: David Silva
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: His Manchester City team-mates call him Merlin because of his magical touch and his ability to conjure chances from nothing. He has also begun scoring more, with his haul of 12 goals from the 2014-15 season representing the first time he has reached double figures in the Premier League. Injury has hampered him recently but when he has played he has elevated City's game to a higher plane, bringing out the the best in the gifted players around him, especially Sergio Agüero and, increasingly, Raheem Sterling. He helped Spain reached Euro 2016 and is likely to gain his 100th cap at the tournament.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Luka Modric
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Real Madrid are not the same side when Luka Modric is missing. They slumped when he was out in January and February, while the Croatian was absent for both legs of the Champions League semi-final defeat to Juventus. That was a huge blow, because Madrid struggle for fluency without his prompting in midfield. Modric is a delightful player, scheming and probing with his passing, winning the ball back with his appreciation of space, and Rafael Benítez needs him to stay fit. Madrid look lost without their playmaker and his injuries disrupted their flow. It cannot be a coincidence that they won nothing last season.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Douglas Costa
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The third-highest new entry on this year's list, Douglas Costa has been terrorising full-backs since joining Bayern Munich from Shakhtar Donetsk in the summer. The Brazilian was an important signing for Bayern, whose hopes of winning the Champions League last season were disrupted when Arjen Robben and Franck Ribéry suffered injuries, and his dazzling wing play has given them a new edge. Bayern are not narrow any more. Costa is comfortable on either flank, dribbling down the outside on the left or cutting inside and shooting with his left foot from the right, and he has combined wonderfully with Robert Lewandowski.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Karim Benzema
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: No matter what he may or may not get up to off the pitch, Karim Benzema is still one of the best strikers around. Even though this year has not been his best, and Rafael Benítez demanded he improve his finishing, Benzema has maintained a respectable strike rate and demonstrated his marksmanship with a crisp Champions League hat-trick against Malmo in December. Benzema also brings more than just goals, as his movement and snappy passing have made him a particularly useful accomplice for Cristiano Ronaldo.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gianluigi Buffon
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: You might expect a player to start sliding down this list as they approach their 38th birthday. Buffon has done the opposite, soaring upwards after a year in which he reminded everyone why he is nicknamed Superman. He played a major part in Juventus’s run to the Champions League final, and his one-handed stop from Dani Alves in that match finished third in the voting for Uefa’s save of the season. Buffon’s reflexes remain razor sharp, and he transmits confidence to his defensive colleagues like few others could. Two of our judges named him as their No1 player overall.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Toni Kroos
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A player who had the world at his feet after winning the World Cup has stumbled this year and Toni Kroos could be forgiven for wondering if leaving Bayern Munich for Real Madrid was the right decision. The German has dropped 24 places in our rankings and he has not looked comfortable at the Bernabéu recently. He should be taking games by the scruff of the neck, but he is drifting aimlessly at the moment. He has only scored one goal for Madrid in 2015 and his performance in the 4-0 defeat to Barcelona last month was deeply worrying.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thibaut Courtois
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A Premier League winner in his first season in the Chelsea side, after three years establishing his reputation on loan at Atlético Madrid, and decisive with his contribution throughout the glittering 2014-15 campaign. Yet Thibaut Courtois was sent off on the opening day this time round and, once restored after suspension, damaged the meniscus in his knee to leave him on the outside looking in for three months. That would explain the dip in his standing and, while Asmir Begovic is a capable understudy, the ailing champions clearly missed a player José Mourinho considers “the best goalkeeper in the world”.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sergio Ramos
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Manchester United understandably did their utmost to lure this outstanding all-round defender away from Real Madrid in the summer but Sergio Ramos played the clubs as expertly as he plays opponents and ended up signing a lucrative new contract as well as gaining the Real Madrid captaincy. At 29, and despite fitness problems and a public clash with Real manager Rafael Benítez in October, he remains a wonderful asset for club and country thanks to his leadership, power and intelligence as well as his refined skills, versatility and even his goal threat – as exemplified by his sensational bicycle kick goal against Sevilla in November.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Harry Kane
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It was tempting last season to wonder who wrote Harry Kane's scripts. Having burst onto the Premier League scene in Roy of the Rovers style, he marked his debut for England in March by scoring with his third touch against Lithuania. Kane has continued this season where he left off the last, running tirelessly for Tottenham Hotspur and setting the tone for Mauricio Pochettino's pressing style while scoring goals at a healthy rate. Kane has borne the pressure of being the only recognised striker currently at the club, and his strength, burst of pace and directness mark him out. This year's fourth highest new entry is the only Englishman in the top 50.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Ángel di María
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: This year has been a bit of a rollercoaster for Ángel di María, who drops 25 places in the Top 100. It started badly with six difficult months at Manchester United, with problems on and off the pitch. The Argentinian, still only 27, was not happy at Old Trafford and PSG came to his rescue. The French champions bought him for €63m just a year after missing out on him, and the move revived Di María’s year. He had an immediate impact on Paris with goal, assists, pace, energy and talent as the right side of the front three he forms with Zlatan Ibrahimovic and Edinson Cavani.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Diego Godín
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: No one really talks about Diego Godín outside Spain and not even that many talk about him inside Spain, but they should. This summer, Atlético Madrid signed eight players and sold eight players, in transfers worth over €200m, but it was the deal that they did not do that might have been the most important. Clubs wanted Godín, but Atlético were not selling. Instead, they renewed his contract, so keen were they to keep him. “We made an effort with Godín,” Simeone said. “His work and the way that he approaches the game mentally put him in a very special place.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thiago Silva
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For Thiago Silva, it is all about continuing his recovery from the 2014 World Cup. The whole competition was a traumatic experience for him but he has responded very well. This year has probably been the best of his career. “O Monstro" turned 31 in September and he was back to his best, defensively, and thrived as PSG’s leader on and off the pitch. He scored a crucial goal against Chelsea in the Champions League last 16, second leg at Stamford Bridge that clinched his side's place in the quarter-finals on away goals. Dunga, Brazil’s head coach, is still not calling him up though.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Andrea Pirlo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Thirty-six years old, and still holding strong inside the top 50 on our list. But while Andrea Pirlo has slipped 13 places, his inclusion here is not a romantic one. With Pirlo nestled at the base of their midfield, Juventus collected a domestic double, winning Serie A by 17 points – as well as reaching the Champions League final – and he perfectly complemented the more athletic players around him with a frightening range of passing. Without the same protection at New York City FC, his defensive frailties have been exposed but he remains one of the greats.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marco Verratti
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: “There are few players as good as him, he plays at an extraordinary level” – that was the verdict delivered in November by none other than the former Barcelona maestro, Xavi, who said that Marco Verratti “plays the way that I tried to play”. There are very few midfielders who possess the dynamism and range of passing of Verratti, who exerts an influence on matches out of all proportion to his small size. He was instrumental in PSG's conquest of Ligue 1 and both domestic French cups, along with their progress to the last eight of the Champions League. And he has even responded favourably to Laurent Blanc's demand for better discipline, appearing far less frequently in referees' notebooks.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gerard Piqué
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Gerard Piqué seems to have pulled himself together in 2015. His drop in form last year was widely noted but, while Barcelona’s front three have deservedly taken most of the plaudits for their remarkable form, their defence has only conceded 24 times in its last 47 league games and the 28-year-old has been showing the kind of leadership that should be expected at this stage of his career. His receipt of the Catalan Player of the Year award suggests his efforts are appreciated locally, although not everybody agrees – he has been booed by Spain supporters in recent months, seemingly due to his support for a referendum on Catalan independence and occasional swipes at Real Madrid. Climbs 49 places in this year's list.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jérôme Boateng
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Bayern Munich centre-back used to suffer from temporary lapses of concentration; he lost his 2013 Champions League medal at Wembley, too. In the last couple of years, however, the Berlin-born World Cup winner with Germany in Brazil has evolved into one of the most dependable defenders on the planet. Jérôme Boateng’s athleticism, pace and enormous, Beckenbauer-grade passing range (“he plays like the Kaiser,” Thomas Müller said of his team-mate) set him apart from his peers, the slight misfortune of having his legs twisted by Barcelona’s Lionel Messi in the 2015 Champions League semi-final notwithstanding.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Philippe Coutinho
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Being left out of Brazil's World Cup squad in 2014 seems to have spurred Philippe Coutinho on to a higher level. He has since proved himself as one of the biggest creative talents in the Premier League and a schemer his national side badly need. His excellent form was the one constant throughout a patchy year for Liverpool and that was recognised in his nomination for PFA player of the year. Several of his goals could feature in a highlights reel of spectacular strikes from 2015 and, after being the brightest player towards the end of Brendan Rodgers' reign at Anfield, he has continued to flourish under Jürgen Klopp. Fifth highest new entry in this year's Top 100.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Álvaro Morata
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Last season was a breakthrough one for Álvaro Morata, who had become a useful squad player at Real Madrid without really looking like becoming a regular. His move to Juventus was the right one and this sharp all-rounder of a striker has thrived, scoring 15 goals and briefly giving his team hope in the Champions League final when he equalised against Barcelona. There was also a first goal for Spain – the winner in a Euro 2016 qualifier against Ukraine in March. Things have not come as easily this season; a calf injury hampered him early on and Juventus, runaway winners of Serie A last term, have started slowly. By early December Morata had not scored in 12 games, but he is not the type to hide. Sixth highest new entry this year.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Gonzalo Higuaín
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A lesser character than Gonzalo Higuaín would have been crushed by the events of this summer. First the striker missed a crucial penalty against Lazio that would have put Napoli on course for a Champions League berth. Then he did it again in the final of the Copa América, blazing over in Argentina’s shoot-out defeat to Chile. But instead of throwing in the towel, Higuaín resolved to get better – working with Leo Messi’s dietician to shed four kilograms over the summer and arrive for this season in the best shape of his life. He has been nigh on unstoppable since.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Xabi Alonso
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Whether it is starting a quick transition or dropping into central defence, it is Xabi Alonso's tactical intelligence that Pep Guardiola values almost as much as his technical ability. That Alonso fell 28 places from his position in last year's list says more about his stellar 2014 than shortcomings this year but an ageing body and the arrival of Arturo Vidal has reduced Bayern's reliance on the 34-year-old. That said, he remains an essential cog in the best-oiled machine in world football. "It was clear Alonso was royalty after our first training session together,” Steven Gerrard wrote in his autobiography earlier this year. “He was, by some distance, the best central midfielder I ever played alongside.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marco Reus
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Dortmund never doubted that Marco Reus, their thrilling winger, would regain his best form following the injuries that hampered him last year. That is why in February they offered him a new contract, and he agreed to stay at the club that reared him despite interest from practically all of Europe's elite. Sure enough, he has been brilliant since then, continuing to shred defences with rapid runs, skill and regular goals. He scored in Dortmund's opening Bundesliga match – a 4-0 destruction of Mönchengladbach – and then struck a hat-trick against Odd to secure qualification for the Europa League group stages. He has remained a regular threat throughout this season, one of his goals setting up the win at Wolfsburg that confirmed Dortmund as Bayern Munich's closest chasers in Germany.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Diego Costa
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A player who was Chelsea's greatest asset last season has arguably become their biggest problem this time around, hence his nosedive down the table. Diego Costa was an inspiration over the first half of last term, a regular scorer and disrupter of opposing defences, but has been blunt since January. Retrospective punishments for on-field issues have not helped, and have unsettled his aggressive gameplan, but he has started to slip into Fernando Torres' bad habits, drifting into the channels to give the impression of industry and endeavour while avoiding the box, where Chelsea need him most, for fear of missing chances.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Willian
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Arguably the only player to enhance his reputation at Chelsea this season, Willian is a new entry this year having flourished at Stamford Bridge while almost all his team-mates have floundered. There is always one previously unheralded, or even unnoticed, player who tends to raise his game while others struggle and Willian has provided the goals – largely from expertly dispatched set-pieces – energy and industry so lacking elsewhere in the champions' lineup. The Brazilian's form might normally be considered revelatory had he not cost £32m when snatched from Tottenham Hotspur's grasp back in 2013.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Blaise Matuidi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The high-power engine in the midfield of a Paris Saint-Germain side that did the domestic double and reached the quarter-finals of the Champions League, deservedly dumping out Chelsea on the way. In addition to his exceptional anticipation and ball-winning skills, Blaise Matuidi is a regular contributor to attacks, thanks both to his passing prowess and his knack for well-timed runs into the box. He also has the ability to score from distance, a spectacular volleyed goal from 20 yards against Serbia in September underlining his increasing importance to his country. Didier Deschamps confirmed that by making him France's captain for the match against Denmark the following month.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Edinson Cavani
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: His touch might be a bit heavy at times and he still regularly misses chances but 2015 has been another high-scoring year for Edinson Cavani, despite playing on the left hand side for PSG and despite being in the shadow of Zlatan Ibrahimovic. He managed to go on several scoring sprees: 12 goals in eight games in all competitions between April and May, plus six in four in September. At 28, he not only brings goals but also works very hard for the team, especially defensively.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Miralem Pjanic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Having learned his trade under the legendary dead-ball specialist Juninho Pernambucano at Lyon, Miralem Pjanic has a claim to be the best free-kick taker in the world, scoring five set-pieces for Roma this season alone. It is in open play, however, that the 25-year-old has developed into one of Serie A's best midfielders – his quick feet and quicker thinking in tight spaces is often spellbinding. For all his talent, Pjanic has yet to win any major honours: Roma finished second in Serie A last season. Perhaps the arrival of his compatriot Edin Dzeko at the club will help them go one better.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Raphaël Varane
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Real Madrid's Raphaël Varane started 2015 with probably the best tackle of the year. With Atlético's Antoine Griezmann clean through, Varane used his searing pace to gain five yards on his fleet-footed compatriot, before executing an inch-perfect slide inside his own penalty box. Perhaps no other centre-back would have caught Griezmann. First choice for Real and France, Varane will be at the heart of any success the Euro 2016 hosts have next summer. Still just 22, he already reads the game like an old hand and has time on his side to become the world's best defender.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Vincent Kompany
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Vincent Kompany’s form for Manchester City often left much to be desired last season and it is not a surprise to see him drop so far down the list. He made costly mistakes at the back and he was even dropped after the defeat to Liverpool in March. However, City still find it difficult to play without their captain and leader. Kompany has improved this season and it is worth noting that, by mid December, City had only conceded three goals when he had been on the pitch, compared to 20 when he had been missing. City will continue to suffer setbacks if Kompany’s fitness problems do not go away.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Dani Alves
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It looked possible that Dani Alves would leave Barcelona in the summer. What a mistake that would have been, particularly in the midst of Barça's transfer embargo. Now with a new contract and playing with a smile on his face again, Alves remains every bit as important for Barcelona's width going forward – no other player has provided more assists for Lionel Messi in the last five years – and he finally seems to have learned some positional play in defence, reflected in his rise of 23 places from last year. New signing Aleix Vidal will provide competition from January, so Alves can't afford to let up.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Hulk
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Two months after signing a contract extension with Zenit St Petersburg, Hulk netted a superb free-kick to clinch the Russian title for his team and confirm his status as the league's top scorer. He has continued his strong form this season, including in the Champions League, where he was previously accused of shrinking when it really mattered. Two magnificent strikes in the 3-2 win at Valencia silenced that criticism and he followed that up with a fine performance and another goal in the win over Lyon as Zenit cruised through the group stage.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Wayne Rooney
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Let’s begin with the positives. Wayne Rooney finally broke Sir Bobby Charlton’s England goalscoring record in September, an achievement that merits genuine acclaim. What else? He scored a hat-trick against Club Brugge. He slapped a wrestler in the face. Yet the negatives are impossible to ignore. Rooney turned 30 in October and his decline has left him open to accusations that he is over the hill. While he is not the only Manchester United striker who has struggled under Louis van Gaal, stylistic concerns cannot mask Rooney’s stodgy performances and his poor touch. He has fallen 17 places in this list and he is a shadow of his former self.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Alexandre Lacazette
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The year started like a dream for Alexandre Lacazette. At 24, the Lyon and France striker went through the best period of his young career. Everything he tried would end up in the net. He scored 13 in his 16 games for his club between January and May, finishing the 2014-15 season as the top scorer in Ligue 1 with 27 goals in his 33 league appearances. The Top 100 newcomer's tally was way ahead of Zlatan Ibrahimovic or Edinson Cavani. The second part of 2015 has been more difficult, both for Lacazette and Lyon, but 2015 will forever remain the year he made a name for himself.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Raheem Sterling
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Raheem Sterling's career at Liverpool ended with something of a whimper, in terms of form, and a whine in terms of the reaction of the fans he left behind. He has since set about showing why Manchester City were prepared to pay a fee potentially rising to £49m for his services, as his pace and creativity have enhanced his new side. He is also blessed with precocious strength and composure and a hat-trick against Bournemouth in October suggested his efforts to improve his finishing are starting to bear fruit, though there is plainly still work to be done. That lone flaw notwithstanding, he is a crucial player for club and country.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Cesc Fàbregas
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The Spain international endured a worryingly characteristic dip in form over the second half of last season, and has appeared lethargic and disorientated at times to date since, reflecting Chelsea's collective and ongoing issues. Cesc Fàbregas can be a conveyor belt of chances, as his tally of assists last season proved, but the World Cup winner is struggling now to influence contests consistently whether he starts as a No10 or in a deeper-lying role. The class and quality is in there somewhere, but Chelsea have not seen enough of it and that has steadily undermined his influence within the side.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Yacine Brahimi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Yacine Brahimi is one of the most exciting players in European club football thanks to his trickery, ability to change direction in a flash and eagerness to attack from all angles. Only Lionel Messi and Eden Hazard completed more dribbles than him during the 2014-15 Champions League campaign and, crucially, the Algeria international has substance as well as style, as he tends to conclude his jarring runs with well-aimed passes or ferocious shots. He finished last season with a career-high 13 goals and his performances persuaded his club to revise his buy-out clause upwards to over £43m.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Carlos Bacca
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A move to Milan is not the career pinnacle it once was and Carlos Bacca has had to tough out a stodgy start to the season from Sinisa Mihajlovic’s underwhelming side. Six goals by early November showed, at least, that the Colombian striker had settled well and continued the form that brought 49 in two seasons for Sevilla. The two he scored in the Europa League final against Dnipro ensured he would have played Champions League football had he stayed. Energetic, direct and a buzzing menace to defenders, Bacca has the kind of style that raises the intensity of those around him; his passion overspilled during the Copa América though, when he was sent off for shoving Neymar and banned for two games.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Anthony Martial
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: There was little chance of Anthony Martial arriving at Manchester United quietly – not when he had been prised from Monaco for an eyewatering initial £36m at the age of just 19. It was an astonishing fee for a player who, while he had hit form with eight goals in the last two months of 2014-15, still fell into the ‘raw potential’ bracket, but the deal looked far-sighted when he scored thrillingly on his debut against Liverpool and followed that with two more at Southampton. Things have not come as easily since then; Martial has a heady blend of pace and power but needs support while his game develops – and he has not had a great deal of service to take advantage of at United, either.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Keylor Navas
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: On transfer deadline day, Keylor Navas waited in a lounge at the airport, gazing at the plane that he thought was going to take him to Manchester United, a makeweight in the David de Gea deal. In the end, though, Real Madrid did not get the deal done. Navas returned to a club that did not want him. “Many things” went though his head, he admitted. He recalled thinking: “I don’t want to go but if I have to go it is because that’s God will ... And in the end God didn’t want me to go. He gave me the opportunity and I don’t want to waste it.” He did not waste it. He might have been sunk, but instead he was strong. His performances were so good, in fact, that while Real Madrid were disappointed not to sign De Gea, they became grateful that the Costa Rican was sticking around. What most sets Navas apart is the speed, the legwork. Then there’s his attitude: there is a quiet, straight, toughness to him, a conviction, a clarity, a competitive determination that is unwavering. His focus is such that even some team-mates find it a little intense, almost comic at times, but it is the reason he has succeeded. When he was at Levante, he made more saves than any other goalkeeper in Spain. He faces fewer shots these days but, before the clásico, he had saved a higher percentage than any other goalkeeper in the country: over 90%. When Real Madrid beat Celta, the Celta striker Nolito remarked: “It’s down to Keylor. He made three or four saves [so good] that I have no idea how he made them.” Watching at home, James Rodríguez described him as “incredible”. The former Real Madrid striker Emilio Butragueño called him “miraculous.”

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jamie Vardy
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Panto season is upon us and, if he were not otherwise engaged, Jamie Vardy would be the ideal person to play Cinderella. Because this spectacular new entry in the Top 100 has lived a fairytale year, completing his rise from non-league journeyman to ace Premier League marksman and England international. With a record-breaking scoring sequence he has spearheaded Leicester's success and with his speed and relentlessness he has epitomised his team's most endearing qualities. His form has been such that in January his club will probably have to fend off suitors, and in the summer his country will unleash him on Europe's elite.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mohamed Salah
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Mohamed Salah seems exactly the kind of vibrant talent that – wait for it – Chelsea could make use of at the moment. Even if the Egyptian was not quite ready for regular Premier League football when he arrived at Stamford Bridge in January 2014, it seemed rash to loan him to Fiorentina a year later in return for the similarly ill-starred Juan Cuadrado and even more so when he scored nine times in a blistering three-month spell in Italy. He was then allowed to join Roma and the pattern has been similar. A 23-year-old with his speed, flair and ability to play in a number of attacking positions can only keep improving – and seems to fit the mould of player that his former employers are seeking in January. They could have saved themselves the trouble.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Koke
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Signed by Atlético at the age of eight, Koke has grown up to become the club's heart and soul on the pitch. An indefatigable warrior, he is fundamental to Diego Simeone's team, the embodiment of its spirit as well as a tough and technically exquisite player who can excel in a variety of positions across midfield. He creates constantly, scores occasionally and never drops his commitment nor allows anyone else to. He is the thread running through all his team's moves, whether playing for Atlético or Spain.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Giorgio Chiellini
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A defender's defender. There is not an ounce of libero in Giorgio Chiellini and that's the way he, and so many others, like it. Street-smart and fearless, last season he formed a formidable partnership with Leonardo Bonucci to help Juve to the double. This season, when Juventus got off to a shocker, Massimiliano Allegri needed a leader, especially following the departure of so many senior players in the summer. Chiellini was just that and, since September, Juve have conceded very few goals in the league when he has been on the pitch.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Jordi Alba
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Opponents tasked with bothering Barcelona's left-back usually find themselves running backwards, or in circles, desperately trying to keep track of the marauding Jordi Alba. There was a memorable moment during Real Madrid's 4-0 humiliation at the Bernabéu in November when Luka Modric and James Rodríguez almost collided with each other as they tried to subdue the defender, who then backheeled the ball into the path of Andrés Iniesta as Barça attacked anew. Blessed with skill, cunning and phenomenal speed, he is a huge asset to Barcelona, whom he helped to the treble last season before contributing richly to Spain's qualification for Euro 2016, scoring in the important 2-0 win over Slovakia.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Yevhen Konoplyanka
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Orthodox wingers tend to fall in and out of vogue but Yevhen Konoplyanka provides one of the best arguments for sticking with the wide man. The Ukrainian is an exhilarating prospect when in full flight, capable of outstripping defenders at will and particularly lethal when cutting inside and shooting from range. He closed an eight-year spell at Dnipro after starring in their run to last season’s Europa League final; Stoke were strongly linked but he eventually opted to join Sevilla, where he has fitted in quickly enough to be linked with Real Madrid. Konoplyanka’s continuing good form will be critical to Ukraine’s hopes for a respectable showing at Euro 2016.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Bastian Schweinsteiger
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It has been an odd year for Bastian Schweinsteiger. He won another Bundesliga title with Bayern but fell out of favour with Pep Guardiola. His transfer to Manchester United was celebrated as astute business on their part yet his performances of late have been underwhelming, which have led some to question his role as the captain of Germany. Rated in the top 25 last year, he has slipped 49 places. Rarely flustered, the World Cup winner remains a player who always seems to have time on the ball, but the clock appears to be ticking on one of the great club and international careers.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mats Hummels
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Perennially linked with a move away from Borussia Dortmund, it is somewhat surprising that the 26 year-old centre-back is still playing at Signal Iduna Park. Mats Hummels endured a turbulent 2014-15 season in which Dortmund flirted with relegation before recovering to qualify for the Europa League and his mentor, Jürgen Klopp, left the club. While he is prone to the odd error he is still a fixture with the German national team, reading the game well and proving dominant in the air. Hummels's form has picked up again, with Dortmund beginning the 2015-16 season with a 13-game unbeaten run. The World Cup winner seems to have been around a long time but is still young enough to improve further, wherever that may be.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Franck Ribéry
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A year to forget for the winger, who made only seven appearances for Bayern Munich in February and March before suffering a complicated ankle injury against Shakhtar Donetsk that he is still yet to fully recover from. With Douglas Costa impressing in his place, the former France winger may struggle to reach the heights that have made him one of the past decade's most consistent performers. If he can prove his fitness his experience could be key as Bayern Munich juggle a busy set of fixtures and attempt to repeat the treble heroics of 2013.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Henrikh Mkhitaryan
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The problem for Henrikh Mkhitaryan is that, with Bayern Munich so utterly dominant in the Bundesliga, it may be difficult for him to keep improving in his current surroundings. He is not doing a bad job of looking a cut above most of the competition though. After a 2014/15 season blighted by injuries and patchy form – which could also be said more broadly for his club, Borussia Dortmund – the Armenian attacking midfielder has been excellent in their revival under Thomas Tuchel and had scored eight goals by 5 November. Liverpool were heavily linked in the summer, and those murmurs may get louder given the identity of their new manager; if Dortmund cannot run Bayern close this year a new challenge may well be in order.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Arda Turan
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The only Turkish player on the list, the energetic midfielder Arda Turan's slide down the rankings is down to his move from Atlético Madrid to Barcelona in the summer, which meant he has not played club football since May 2015 due to the European champions' transfer embargo. The buzzy 28-year-old creator with the big beard was loved by Diego Simeone and will be hugely missed by Atlético. He was very unlucky to be sent off in the Champions League quarter-final against Real Madrid, a decision that swung the tightest of ties in Real's favour. A player capable of occupying a variety of midfield positions, he should slip into Barça's well-oiled machine seamlessly, with his spatial awareness, dribbling skill and vision perhaps shining brighter than ever before.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Petr Cech
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A re-entry in the Top 100, the commanding Czech goalkeeper Petr Cech has demonstrated his enduring class, both on and off the field, since his summer transfer from Chelsea to Arsenal. Frustrated at being pressed down the Stamford Bridge pecking order by Thibaut Courtois, he pushed for the move and it was not just any move. José Mourinho did not want him to join Chelsea's cross-town rivals but Roman Abramovich afforded Cech the respect of allowing him to choose his next club. He chose Arsenal and, apart from a bad game against West Ham United on his Premier League debut, he has settled seamlessly. A leader in the dressing room, he has been consistently solid and sometimes eye-catching.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mario Götze
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: There is little shame in being unable to top a World Cup final-deciding year but the nagging feeling is that Götze could be doing slightly more. Nobody is asking him to stand head and shoulders above the galaxy of talent at Bayern Munich but this has been a relatively humdrum 12 months: he has struggled to make his mark on big games and goals have largely dried up, too. It says something about Götze's majestic early career that he is being judged by these standards but you wonder whether he and Pep Guardiola, who has been reluctant to use him over a full 90 minutes, are the best of fits. Matters have not been helped by a groin injury, sustained in October, that will sideline him until 2016. Tumbles 56 places in our list this year.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Thiago Alcântara
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Thiago Alcântara returned to action in April after missing a year through injury – and he instantly made his presence felt, scoring the decisive penalty in a shoot-out victory over Bayer Leverkusen. Later that month the midfielder scored in both legs of the Champions League quarter-final crushing of Porto and he ended the season collecting his second Bundesliga title. His blossoming helped persuade Bayern to relinquish Bastian Schweinsteiger and Alcântara has filled that gap and then some, orchestrating Bayern's dominance from midfield thanks to immaculate technique and intelligence. Arsenal, for one, could not get close to him during their humiliation at the Allianz Arena in November.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Mauro Icardi
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Serie A’s youngest capocannoniere since Paolo Rossi in 1978, Mauro Icardi has finally begun to make headlines with his endeavours on the pitch instead of off it. Previously best known for pairing up with Wanda Nara, the glamour model ex-wife of former team-mate Maxi López, he remains popular with gossip columnists but has won over Inter’s supporters with his ruthlessness in front of goal. Still only 22 years old, Icardi is a phenomenally efficient striker with a knack for showing up in the biggest games – and especially against Juventus – though he has made a slower start to this campaign.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Nolito
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: First he beat them, now there is a fair chance he will rejoin them. When Nolito’s goal and two assists inspired Celta Vigo to a stunning 4-1 win over his old club, Barcelona, in September it added to the talk that he will return to Camp Nou in January – a switch that would complete the delightful late blossoming of one of La Liga’s most watchable talents. Inspired by Nolito, modest Celta finished eighth last season and sit fourth now; the goals have flowed from his perch on the left of the attack and he has made it into the Spain squad, too. Nolito has always had talent – he displayed it for a year at Benfica after leaving Barça – and, at 29, he would not be begrudged the chance to prove himself at last on the biggest stage of all.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Claudio Bravo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Claudio Bravo won the domestic double and the European Cup with Barcelona, keeping 22 clean sheets, and helped Chile claim the Copa América title for the first time in nearly a century. Not a bad 2015. His point-blank stop from Sergio Agüero in the Copa América final was every bit as important as his stand-out performance in the shoot-out. He has became known as something of a spot-kick specialist, making a crucial penalty save in the edgy home victory over Valencia in April that put Barcelona on their way to a 23rd league title. He is a good footballer too. The Catalans have not missed Víctor Valdés one bit.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Javier Pastore
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Javier Pastore, the 26-year-old Argentinian midfielder, makes the Top 100 for the first time in his career. It's as a result of a very good first half of the year in which Pastore was a creative force at PSG, adding a touch of class every time he played for the French champions, and was a key player in clinching the league title. This was also the year the former Palermo star made his return for the national team. Tata Martino, Argentina’s head coach, rates him highly. It is a shame, though, that injuries have prevented him from playing much since the summer.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Memphis Depay
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Being Dutch does not cut you extra slack under Louis van Gaal – as Robin van Persie would know – and the manager was not pulling many punches in November when he said more had been hoped for from Memphis Depay since his summer arrival. Depay cost £25m from PSV Eindhoven and, like Anthony Martial, bears weighty expectations on young shoulders. There have been some successes – he scored twice cutting in from the left against Club Brugge and was convincing when used more centrally at Watford  – but he has so far struggled to replicate the performances that brought 43 goals for PSV. Still, Depay is just 21 and, in the right hands, should mature to display his explosive talents more consistently.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Juan Mata
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Juan Mata's speed shortage means he has not always been Louis van Gaal's preferred option but the Spaniard has made an impact whenever called upon, offering creativity and sharpness that Manchester United often lack otherwise. He has a good habit of scoring important goals, some of them spectacular – such as the bicycle kick against Liverpool in March, one of two goals he hit that day to secure a 2-1 win. That performance, along with similarly fine ones against Manchester City and Crystal Palace, helped United return to the Champions League.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Marcelo
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: You could be forgiven for thinking Marcelo has been around forever. To be fair, nine years can feel that long if you take a minute interest in Real Madrid’s soap opera but the 27-year-old has shaken off the competition and achieved an admirable level of consistency. Just ask Fabio Coentrão, his most recent rival for the left-back role, who was packed off on loan to Monaco at the start of the season; Marcelo is technically ahead of almost anyone in his position and had a fine 2014-15 season, although he has missed a few games this term through injury. He is only two years from matching Roberto Carlos, the man he replaced, for longevity and few would say he has not done that for quality, too.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Alex Teixeira
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Shakhtar Donetsk’s production line of Brazilian talents shows little sign of slowing. Alex Teixeira has actually been with the club since 2010, when he was just 20, but his form in an otherwise flat Champions League campaign has set the vultures hovering and his manager, Mircea Lucescu, says he will not be sold for less than €40m. He has been mentioned in connection with Chelsea – although he is far from alone in that – and whoever puts up the money would get a diminutive, quick-footed attacking midfielder with a remarkable knack of getting on the end of things. Teixeira scored 22 goals in all competitions last season and, staggeringly, amassed the same number in his first 15 domestic games this time around.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Dimitri Payet
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Dimitri Payet deserved better than for his year to be cut short, but James McCarthy’s rash challenge on the West Ham playmaker in November ruled him out for at least three months and may have dealt a fatal blow to his club’s chances of a European place, too. That the latter is the case says everything about the impact Payet has had since joining from Marseille in August. He picked up the pace of the Premier League straightaway, scoring five times in his first nine outings. In his final season in Ligue 1, he had made 17 assists. In Payet, who turns 29 in March, Slaven Bilic’s side have a technically superb, diligent talent who will hope for a return to the France squad in time for Euro 2016.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Isco
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: For a period towards the end of last season there was a clamour for Real's play to revolve around this young gem rather than Cristiano Ronaldo. Rash, possibly, but definitely a tribute to the form that Isco was showing at a time when several more vaunted players were performing below par. His marvellous dribbling, precise crossing and all-round vision make him a creator of rare quality, attributes he now shows on a regular basis for Spain, too.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Leonardo Bonucci
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The silk alongside the steel of Giorgio Chiellini and Andrea Barzagli in Juventus's mean defence. A former midfielder whose passing game and vision have been key to Juve's four consecutive league titles, Leonardo Bonucci takes a place in our top 100 for the first time since 2012. Won the double in 2015 and helped Juventus to become the first Italian Champions League finalists since José Mourinho's Inter in 2010. Chips in with his fair share of goals from set pieces, using his aerial ability to good effect. His cool presence in central defence was a key factor as Italy qualified for Euro 2016 undefeated.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Carlos Sánchez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Time was when only one player nicknamed "Pato" would have been considered for this list. While Alexandre was finding the net for Milan five years ago, Carlos Sánchez was plugging away in mid-career for the unfashionable Mendoza-based side Godoy Cruz. But since his dream move to River Plate the 31-year-old Uruguayan has, slightly late in the day, become one of South America’s most sought-after talents. The next to benefit will be the Mexican side Monterrey, who the right-sided attacking midfielder will join just months after scoring four times in River’s first Copa Libertadores success since 1996. Among those contributions was a decisive penalty in the controversial last-16 tie with Boca; it is fair to say Sánchez, who has scored some spectacular goals, will not be forgotten.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Sebastian Giovinco
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Sebastian Giovinco’s decision to join Toronto in January 2015 was met with incredulity in Italy. Here was a player who should have been in the prime of his career, 28 years old and an Italy international, turning his back on Serie A in favour of Major League Soccer. As reports trickled in of a $7m per year salary, more than one prominent commentator accused him of selling out his childhood dream of becoming the Juventus No10. But Giovinco was not the one in need of a reality check. This was his sixth season at Juventus, split across three different spells, and he was no closer to that No10 shirt than he had ever been. Successive managers had failed to get the most from him and now, under Massimiliano Allegri, he was having a hard time finding space in the team. What Toronto promised, more than money, was a chance to be a leading man. Giovinco grasped that opportunity with both hands, becoming the first player ever to finish as MLS’s (joint) top scorer and leading assist man in the same year. The numbers alone could not do justice to the sheer entertainment of watching him play. As Giovinco’s confidence returned, so did the feints, touches and tricks that we had seen so regularly during his best season, four years ago, at Parma, but only intermittently since. One veteran MLS writer observed that every free-kick Giovinco took had become "an event". At Juventus, the player had been shackled – forced to play in positions and systems that did not suit him. Toronto built their plans around him and have reaped the rewards. Giovinco looks more confident than at any time in his career, and has even won back his place in the Italy side after briefly losing it in the wake of his move.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Santi Cazorla
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: A re-entry to the list – he was No67 in 2013 – to reflect his re-emergence at the very highest level. The Spain midfielder has been given a new role by Arsène Wenger at Arsenal, as a deeper-sitting central playmaker, and how he has responded. His quick feet make him a delight to watch and so does the vision and incision of his passing. Wenger has also had cause to highlight the manner in which he reads the game, which helps him with his defensive duties. Ruptured the lateral ligament in his knee at the end of November; club and country are praying that he returns as the same force.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Francesco Totti
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Always a divisive talent, Francesco Totti has had his fair share of critics down the years but provokes such fierce loyalty in his supporters that some celebrate his birthday each September by wishing one another "Merry Christmas". So perhaps we should not be surprised to discover that, while many left him off their lists altogether, one of our panelists defiantly named him as the best player in the world. In truth, he is no longer a fixture of the Roma first XI, but he does remain the club captain and, even at 39, he still has a part to play.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Riyad Mahrez
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: It is hard to believe that Riyad Mahrez once feared he was unsuitable for English football. After joining Leicester in 2014 he helped them to promotion from the Championship and then played a valuable role in their thrilling late dash for survival in the Premier League before an even more eye-catching role in their sensational current season. His speed, trickery and sharpness make Mahrez one of the most exciting players in the Premier League at the moment. His influence for his country has also risen since Algeria's disappointing quarter-final exit in the Africa Cup of Nations last January.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Andriy Yarmolenko
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: The smart money is on Andriy Yarmolenko’s gifts being visible to a wider public before long. The Dynamo Kyiv forward joins Yevhen Konoplyanka in forming one of the world’s most exhilarating wide pairings with the Ukraine national team, for whom he scored three times in the Euro 2016 play-offs, and could even be playing in the Premier League before next summer. Matters might be complicated by the new contract he has signed at Dynamo; he is the club’s talisman and has become a prolific goalscorer, finding the target twice as they reached the Champions League round of 16 for the first time since 1999/2000. A powerful six-footer with a rocket of a left foot, Yarmolenko has enough about him to be successful anywhere.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Nemanja Matic
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: Nemanja Matic was integral last season, screening Chelsea's back line effectively and reclaiming the ball to allow attack-minded team-mates to thrive. There was no better defensive midfielder in the Premier League over that title-winning campaign. Yet perhaps a first full season in English football sapped his energy because, like his team-mates, he has laboured too often this year. There have been signs of late that the Serbian international's leggy energy is restored, with his influence on the rise once more, but a slump of 51 places reflects the reality that he was off the pace and diminished through much of the autumn.

sheets.Sheet1.Name: Laurent Koscielny
sheets.Sheet1.Profile: On New Year's Day 2015 Arsenal suffered a shambolic defeat at Southampton. That pretty much terminated Arsène Wenger's faith in Wojciech Szczesny and marked the start of Arsenal's solidification, a process to which Laurent Koscielny has been integral. As Arsenal have evolved into one of the meanest defences in the Premier League, Koscielny has emerged as one of the best centre-backs. He has also performed well at international level and can expect to start in the heart of France's defence at Euro 2016.
